article.title: sweet alyssum
article.p:
sweet alyssum
Sweet alyssum (
Lobularia maritima
), a common ornamental plant.
Joan E. Rahn/Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.
sweet alyssum
, (
Lobularia maritima
), also called
sweet alison
,
annual
or short-lived
perennial
herb of the mustard family (
Brassicaceae
). It is native to the Mediterranean region. Sweet alyssum is widely grown as a border ornamental for its fragrant clusters of small flowers.

Sweet alyssum has white four-petaled
flowers
; there are horticultural forms with lavender, pink, or purple flowers. The narrow gray-green
leaves
are untoothed and usually bear many silvery hairs. The flowering stalks rise to 30 cm (1 foot), with the small round seedpods, known as
silicles
, developing on the stems below the flower heads.
